title: The rise and fall of the medieval Islamic Empire - Petra Sijpesteijn & Birte Kristiansen

multiple-choice.question: Who united the people of the Arabian Peninsula through the formation of Islam in the 7th century CE?

options.label: B
options.text: Muhammad, the prophet of Islam

options.label: C
options.text: Ali, the fourth caliph of Islam

options.label: D
options.text: Umar ibn Al-Khattab, a companion of Muhammad and the second caliph

multiple-choice.question: What city served as the initial political heart of the empire formed by Muhammad?

options.text: Mecca, a major city in the Arabian Peninsula

options.label: B
options.text: Medina, the city where Muhammad formed the Islamic Empire

options.label: C
options.text: Damascus, the capital of the Umayyad Dynasty

options.label: D
options.text: Baghdad, the capital of the Abbasid Dynasty

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: Umar ibn Al-Khattab, a companion of Muhammad and the second caliph

options.label: C

options.label: B
options.text: The Umayyad Dynasty, who were overthrown by the Abbasids

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: A
options.text: Mecca, a major city in the Arabian Peninsula

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Damascus, the capital of the Umayyad Dynasty

options.label: D

options.label: B
options.text: The caliph was overthrown and exiled

options.label: C
options.text: The city was thoroughly destroyed and the caliph killed

options.label: D

options.label: A
options.text: The empire was unified and strengthened under a new leader

options.label: B
options.text: The empire expanded into new territories and gained more power

options.label: C
options.text: The empire underwent significant reforms to address its weaknesses

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: Can you guess what's wrong with these paintings? - Noah Charney

title: Why a sausage can do what your gloves cannot - Charles Wallace and Sajan Saini

options.label: C

multiple-choice.question: What is the key difference between conductors and insulators in terms of their electrons?

options.label: A
options.text: Conductors have a higher voltage, while insulators have a lower voltage.

options.label: B
options.text: Conductors have weakly bound electrons, while insulators have tightly bound electrons.

options.label: C
options.text: Conductors have a higher resistance, while insulators have a lower resistance.

options.label: D
options.text: Conductors have tightly bound electrons, while insulators have weakly bound electrons.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the conductive substance coating on the layers of a resistive touchscreen?

options.label: A
options.text: To enhance durability and reduce wear.

options.label: B
options.text: To increase sensitivity and responsiveness.

options.label: C
options.text: To complete the electric circuit when the layers connect.

options.label: D
options.text: To reduce resistance and improve conductivity.

multiple-choice.question: Which type of touchscreen is generally easier to use than resistive touchscreens?

options.label: A
options.text: Capacitive touchscreen.

options.label: B
options.text: Resistive touchscreen.

options.label: C
options.text: Optical touchscreen.

options.label: D
options.text: Surface acoustic wave touchscreen.

multiple-choice.question: Why is the human body a good conductor of electricity?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it is made up of tightly bound electrons.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it has a high voltage and resistance.

options.label: C
options.text: Because about 60% of the body is water, which contains impurities that conduct electricity.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the body has a low resistance and high conductivity.

multiple-choice.question: What happens when you try to use a smartphone while your hands are wet or gloved?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: The touchscreen becomes less sensitive but still functional.

options.label: C
options.text: The touchscreen is interrupted, making it difficult to use.

options.label: D
options.text: The touchscreen is not affected and works normally.

multiple-choice.question: What can activate the screen of a capacitive touchscreen?

options.label: A
options.text: Only a human finger.

options.label: B
options.text: Only a conductive object, such as metal.

options.label: C
options.text: A human finger or a conductive object, such as certain metals or foods.

options.label: D
options.text: A human finger or an insulating object, such as fabric.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between capacitive and resistive touchscreens in terms of user interaction?

options.label: A
options.text: Capacitive touchscreens require force to interact, while resistive touchscreens interact directly.

options.label: B
options.text: Capacitive touchscreens are more durable, while resistive touchscreens are less durable.

options.label: C
options.text: Capacitive touchscreens interact directly with the user's finger, while resistive touchscreens require force to interact.

options.label: D
options.text: Capacitive touchscreens have a higher voltage, while resistive touchscreens have a lower voltage.

title: What causes yeast infections, and how do you get rid of them? - Liesbeth Demuyser

multiple-choice.question: Which type of bacteria is commonly found in the vagina and helps maintain its acidic pH, thereby preventing certain infections?

options.label: A
options.text: Lactobacilli

options.label: B
options.text: Candida

options.label: C
options.text: E. coli

options.label: D
options.text: Staphylococcus

options.label: A
options.text: Candida albicans

options.label: B
options.text: Lactobacilli

options.label: C
options.text: E. coli

options.label: D
options.text: Staphylococcus

multiple-choice.question: What happens to Candida albicans when the balance within the vagina is disrupted, such as an increase in pH or a decrease in competing microorganisms?

options.label: A
options.text: It becomes dormant and harmless

options.label: B
options.text: It remains in its normal, harmless form

options.label: C
options.text: It assumes disease-causing forms, multiplying and metamorphosing

options.label: D
options.text: It is killed by the immune system

multiple-choice.question: What are common symptoms of vaginal yeast infections, which can be accompanied by changes in vaginal discharge?

options.label: A
options.text: Itching and fever

options.label: B
options.text: Thick and white vaginal discharge

options.label: C
options.text: Itching, burning, and redness

options.label: D
options.text: Itching, burning, swelling, redness, and thick, white vaginal discharge

multiple-choice.question: What factors can increase a person's susceptibility to vaginal yeast infections?

options.label: A
options.text: Antibiotic treatments

options.label: B
options.text: Hormonal changes

options.label: C
options.text: Lower immunity

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above, including antibiotic treatments, hormonal changes, lower immunity, and other factors such as diet and tight, non-breathable clothing

multiple-choice.question: How can soaps potentially contribute to the development of yeast infections?

options.label: A
options.text: By killing beneficial bacteria

options.label: B
options.text: By disrupting the vaginal pH

options.label: C
options.text: By introducing more Candida to the vagina

options.label: D
options.text: By damaging the protective mucus that coats the vagina

multiple-choice.question: What are recommended treatments for vaginal yeast infections?

options.label: A
options.text: Antibiotic medications

options.label: B
options.text: Antifungal medications

options.label: C
options.text: Probiotics containing harmless yeasts

options.label: D
options.text: B, and preliminary studies suggest possibly C

multiple-choice.question: What is a potential underlying cause of recurrent yeast infections in some individuals, while the causes for others are not yet fully understood?

options.label: A
options.text: Genetic factors

options.label: B
options.text: Hormonal changes and diet

options.label: C
options.text: Semen

options.label: D
options.text: A, and further research is needed to determine other causes

multiple-choice.question: What are some reasons for the lack of research on the vaginal microbiome?

options.label: A
options.text: Due to lack of funding

options.label: B
options.text: Due to stigma surrounding women's health

options.label: C
options.text: Due to lack of interest

options.label: D
options.text: Both A and B

options.label: A
options.text: Antifungal medications

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: Both A and B

title: The world’s slimiest animal - Noah R. Bressman and Douglas Fudge

multiple-choice.question: What type of accident occurred in 2017 involving thousands of kilograms of live hagfish?

options.label: A
options.text: A shipwreck involving a cargo of live animals at sea

options.label: B
options.text: A plane crash involving a cargo plane carrying live animals

options.label: C
options.text: A truck accident where a container fell off and hit an approaching vehicle

options.label: D
options.text: A train derailment involving a cargo of live animals in a rural area

multiple-choice.question: What notable characteristic of hagfish helps them defend against predators?

options.label: A
options.text: Their ability to change color to blend in with their surroundings

options.label: B
options.text: Their sharp, tooth-like structures that can inflict injury

options.label: C
options.text: Their incredibly slimy nature, which deters predators

options.label: D
options.text: Their ability to release a toxic chemical to repel predators

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary purpose of the slime produced by hagfish?

options.label: A
options.text: To communicate with other hagfish over long distances

options.label: B
options.text: To attract prey in dark or murky waters

options.label: C
options.text: To protect themselves from the cold temperatures of the deep sea

options.label: D
options.text: To repel predators and facilitate escape

multiple-choice.question: How does the hagfish's flexible cartilage and loosely attached skin help it avoid damage when caught by a shark?

options.label: A
options.text: By making it harder for the shark to get a good grip

options.label: B
options.text: By providing extra strength to its body to resist the shark's bite

options.label: C
options.text: By allowing its organs to slip out of the way of the shark's bite

options.label: D
options.text: By making it easier for the shark to swallow the hagfish whole

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about the structure of the hagfish's slime?

options.label: A
options.text: It is made up of only mucus, with no other components

options.label: B
options.text: It is made up of only protein fibers, with no mucus

options.label: C
options.text: It is made up of a combination of water and salt, similar to seawater

options.label: D
options.text: It is made up of mucus and reinforced with numerous superfine and strong silk-like fibers

multiple-choice.question: How does the hagfish create liters of slime in a fraction of a second?

options.label: A
options.text: By using a special gland to produce the slime instantly

options.label: B
options.text: By bursting the mucus vesicles and unraveling the protein fibers

options.label: C
options.text: By contracting its muscles to release the slime from its glands

options.label: D
options.text: By combining the contraction of its muscles with the bursting of mucus vesicles and the unraveling of protein fibers

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the hagfish tying itself in a knot?

options.label: A
options.text: To rest and hide from predators in a secure location

options.label: B
options.text: To escape from predators by confusing them

options.label: C
options.text: To remove its own slime and gain leverage to eat its prey

options.label: D
options.text: To attract more predators and create a diversion

multiple-choice.question: What is a potential application of hagfish slime in the field of athletic and safety gear?

options.label: A
options.text: To make materials that are more prone to wear and tear, but cheaper to produce

options.label: B
options.text: To make materials that are more durable and heavy, but less sustainable

options.label: C
options.text: To make materials that are more water-resistant, but less breathable

options.label: D
options.text: To make materials that are more sustainable and rival the properties of materials like nylon

multiple-choice.question: What is a potential military application of hagfish slime?

options.label: A
options.text: To create a device that could be used to detect enemy submarines underwater

options.label: B
options.text: To create a system that could be used to track enemy movements on land

options.label: C
options.text: To create a lethal weapon that could be used to attack enemy soldiers directly

options.label: D
options.text: To create a non-lethal weapon that could be used to stop boats by sliming up their propellers

multiple-choice.question: What is a unique feature of hagfish anatomy?

options.label: A
options.text: They have two hearts, similar to some other fish

options.label: B
options.text: They have three hearts, which pump blood efficiently

options.label: C
options.text: They have a single, large heart that pumps blood throughout their body

options.label: D
options.text: They have four little hearts, which pump blood and other fluids

title: What’s the best country to live in?

multiple-choice.question: Who is credited with inventing the Gross Domestic Product (GDP) in the 1930s?

options.label: A
options.text: King Jigme Singye Wangchuk

options.label: B
options.text: Simon Kuznets

options.label: C
options.text: John Maynard Keynes

options.label: D
options.text: Adam Smith

multiple-choice.question: What does the Gross Domestic Product (GDP) represent?

options.label: A
options.text: The total value of a country's imports and exports

options.label: B
options.text: The total monetary value of everything a country produces and sells on the market

options.label: C
options.text: The total value of a country's natural resources

options.label: D
options.text: The total value of a country's human capital

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following services are not counted in GDP because they are not sold on the market?

options.label: A
options.text: Public school services

options.label: B
options.text: Firefighters services

options.label: C
options.text: Vaccines sales

options.label: D
options.text: Both A and B

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between GDP and Gross National Happiness?

options.label: A
options.text: GDP only considers income per capita, while Gross National Happiness considers only economic growth

options.label: B
options.text: Gross National Happiness factors in matters like health, education, strong communities, and living standards, whereas GDP only measures the total monetary value of goods and services

options.label: C
options.text: GDP only considers environmental burdens of economic growth

options.label: D
options.text: Gross National Happiness only considers income per capita

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, which country is currently the closest to meeting the basic needs of its people while also using resources in a relatively sustainable way?

options.label: A
options.text: Costa Rica

options.label: B
options.text: Colombia

options.label: C
options.text: Jordan

options.label: D
options.text: Bhutan

multiple-choice.question: What is a limitation of using a single number to measure the quality of life in a country?

options.label: A
options.text: It is too complex to understand

options.label: B
options.text: It is too simple to understand

options.label: C
options.text: It doesn't account for differences in priorities among people

options.label: D
options.text: It doesn't capture the full range of factors that affect well-being

multiple-choice.question: Which approach is increasingly favored by experts to measure the quality of life in a country?

options.label: A
options.text: A single, comprehensive metric

options.label: B
options.text: A dashboard approach that considers multiple factors

options.label: C
options.text: The Gross National Happiness approach

options.label: D
options.text: The Sustainable Development Index approach

multiple-choice.question: Who came up with the idea of Gross National Happiness as an alternative to Gross Domestic Product?

options.label: A
options.text: Simon Kuznets

options.label: B
options.text: King Jigme Singye Wangchuk

options.label: C
options.text: John Maynard Keynes

options.label: D
options.text: Adam Smith

multiple-choice.question: What does the Human Development Index (HDI) measure?

options.label: A
options.text: Only income per capita

options.label: B
options.text: Only health and education

options.label: C
options.text: Health, education, and income per capita

options.label: D
options.text: Environmental burdens of economic growth

multiple-choice.question: What does the Sustainable Development Index aim to measure?

options.label: A
options.text: Only well-being

options.label: B
options.text: Only environmental burdens of economic growth

options.label: C
options.text: Only income per capita

options.label: D
options.text: Both well-being and the environmental burdens of economic growth

title: What happens to your body at the top of Mount Everest - Andrew Lovering

multiple-choice.question: What percentage of the barometric pressure at sea level is found at the top of Mt. Everest?
What can happen to people who ascend to high altitudes too quickly?

options.label: A
options.text: They will experience increased oxygen levels in their blood.

options.label: B
options.text: They will develop a form of altitude sickness known as Acute Mountain Sickness (AMS), which can cause headaches, fatigue, and nausea.

options.label: C
options.text: They will experience decreased heart rate and breathing.

options.label: D
options.text: Their bodies will immediately adapt to the high altitude.

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of carotid chemoreceptors in the neck?

options.label: A
options.text: To regulate blood pressure.

options.label: B
options.text: To directly increase heart rate.

options.label: C
options.text: To sense the blood's low oxygen pressure and trigger a response to increase breathing and heart rate.

options.label: D
options.text: To decrease oxygen levels in the blood.

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the volume of plasma in the blood within the first few days above 1,500 meters?

options.label: A
options.text: It increases.

options.label: B
options.text: It decreases.

options.label: C
options.text: It remains the same.

options.label: D
options.text: It fluctuates randomly.

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of the decrease in plasma volume in the blood?

options.label: A
options.text: A decrease in hemoglobin levels.

options.label: B
options.text: An increase in the concentration of hemoglobin.

options.label: C
options.text: No change in hemoglobin levels.

options.label: D
options.text: A decrease in oxygen levels in the blood.

multiple-choice.question: What is the process by which breathing increases even further after several weeks of extended acclimatization?

options.label: A
options.text: Ventilatory acclimatization.

options.label: B
options.text: Cardiovascular adaptation.

options.label: C
options.text: Oxygen acclimatization.

options.label: D
options.text: Altitude acclimatization.

multiple-choice.question: What are the two life-threatening conditions that can occur at altitudes above 3,500 meters due to increased blood vessel pressure?

options.label: A
options.text: High-altitude cerebral edema (HACE) and high-altitude pulmonary edema (HAPE).

options.label: B
options.text: AMS and altitude sickness.

options.label: C
options.text: Oxygen deprivation and altitude sickness.

options.label: D
options.text: Acute mountain sickness and chronic mountain sickness.

multiple-choice.question: What happens to arteries and veins in the brain at high altitudes?

options.label: A
options.text: They constrict to reduce blood flow.

options.label: B
options.text: They dilate to speed up blood flow.

options.label: C
options.text: They remain the same size.

options.label: D
options.text: They have no effect on blood flow.

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of the increased pressure on blood vessels at high altitudes?

options.label: A
options.text: Blood vessels constrict and fluid builds up in the brain and lungs.

options.label: B
options.text: Blood vessels dilate without any fluid buildup.

options.label: C
options.text: Blood vessels remain the same size and fluid builds up in the brain and lungs.

options.label: D
options.text: Blood vessels leak and fluid builds up in the brain and lungs.

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the primary adaptations that occurs within the first few days above 1,500 meters?

options.label: A
options.text: An increase in oxygen levels in the blood.

options.label: B
options.text: An increase in heart rate and breathing rate.

options.label: C
options.text: A decrease in plasma volume, leading to increased hemoglobin concentration.

options.label: D
options.text: An increase in blood pressure.

title: Why can parrots talk? - Grace Smith-Vidaurre and Tim Wright

multiple-choice.question: What happened to a parrot's accent after it went missing for four years and was later reunited with its owner?

options.label: A
options.text: It developed a new accent that was a mix of British and Spanish.

options.label: B
options.text: It lost its British accent and started speaking in Spanish.

options.label: C
options.text: Its accent remained unchanged.

options.label: D
options.text: It gained a new accent from another language it was exposed to.

multiple-choice.question: Which birds are known to produce human-like speech?

options.label: A
options.text: Songbirds and hummingbirds

options.label: B
options.text: Parrots and several other bird species

options.label: C
options.text: Penguins and seagulls

options.label: D
options.text: Owls and eagles

multiple-choice.question: What do wild parrots primarily use vocalizations for?

options.label: A
options.text: To attract prey and protect their territory

options.label: B
options.text: To communicate with other parrots, coordinate group movements, and for mating and territorial displays

options.label: C
options.text: To scare away predators and attract mates

options.label: D
options.text: To regulate their body temperature and find food

multiple-choice.question: How do different parrot species use contact calls to interact with each other?

options.label: A
options.text: All parrot species use individualized contact calls that help them stand out.

options.label: B
options.text: All parrot species use highly similar contact calls that help them blend in.

options.label: C
options.text: Different parrot species use contact calls in varying ways, such as individualized calls in large colonies or shared calls in smaller groups.

options.label: D
options.text: Parrots do not use contact calls at all.

multiple-choice.question: What is a main reason why some parrots can closely imitate a wide range of sounds, including the human voice?

options.label: A
options.text: Their large size and powerful beaks

options.label: B
options.text: Their highly social nature and need for sophisticated mimicry

options.label: C
options.text: Their ability to fly and navigate through dense forests

options.label: D
options.text: Their diet of seeds and nuts

multiple-choice.question: Where does the sound originate in a parrot's body?

options.label: A
options.text: In its larynx, located at the top of its windpipe

options.label: B
options.text: In its syrinx, located at the base of its windpipe

options.label: C
options.text: In its tongue and lips

options.label: D
options.text: In its beak and jaw joints

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about a parrot's syrinx compared to most other birds?

options.label: A
options.text: It has two vibrating membranes

options.label: B
options.text: It has one vibrating membrane, similar to humans

options.label: C
options.text: It has no vibrating membranes

options.label: D
options.text: It has a different shape and size

multiple-choice.question: What do parrots use to shape sounds as they leave their airway?

options.label: A
options.text: Their tongue and lips

options.label: B
options.text: Their beak and jaw joints alone

options.label: C
options.text: Their syrinx and tongue

options.label: D
options.text: Their beak and tongue

multiple-choice.question: What is special about a parrot's brain compared to other birds?

options.label: A
options.text: It has a single song system

options.label: B
options.text: It has an additional circuit that gives them extra flexibility when it comes to learning calls

options.label: C
options.text: It has a smaller size and less complex structure

options.label: D
options.text: It has a different shape and color

options.label: A
options.text: An African grey parrot named Alex

options.label: B
options.text: A blue and gold macaw

options.label: C
options.text: A cockatoo

options.label: D
options.text: A parakeet

multiple-choice.question: Why do parrots often talk in captivity?

options.label: A
options.text: To scare away predators

options.label: B
options.text: To form social bonds with their owners in the absence of their own species

options.label: C
options.text: To regulate their body temperature

options.label: D
options.text: To find food

options.label: A
options.text: Habitat destruction and poaching for the pet trade

options.label: B
options.text: Climate change and pollution

options.label: C
